segments.key_quote: Then as pure self he became free from the material conception of life
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the topic of Yudhishthira Maharaj's detachment and explains the meaning of a verse describing the process of withdrawing from material existence.
segments.transcript: In this session, we will continue to discuss the four principles of the Bhagavad Gita. In the previous session, we had discussed the first half of the purport, and in this session, we will discuss the second half of the purport. Here is a little technical description of how Yudhishthira Maharaj actually cut off all the material attachments when he was preparing to actually go back home, back to Godhead, after relinquishing all his responsibilities by handing them over to his grandson and Krishna's great grandson. So, it was already explained, just to refresh your memory of that time, and we started to learn a little bit more about the verse itself: Vacham Juhava Manasee Tatprana Itareya Tam Mrityav Apanam Sotsargaam Tam Panchatve Hi Ajo Havit. The meaning of this verse is that then He amalgamated all the sense organs into the mind, the mind into life, life into breathing, and its total existence as an entire being, existence into the embodiment of the five elements, and his body into death.

segments.key_quote: Mind should wind up all material activities and be turned towards the transcendental service of the Lord.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the difficulty of giving up material coverings, particularly the gross and subtle bodies, and emphasizes the need to redirect the mind towards transcendental service.

segments.key_quote: The activities of the mind can be changed from matter to devotional service.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that the mind is a reflection of the soul and that its activities should be transformed from material to devotional service to purify it.

segments.key_quote: Begin with spiritual life. Let's say, just chant 108 times Hare Krishna every day.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses how purifying the mind stops the cycle of birth and death and recommends starting with simple spiritual practices like chanting Hare Krishna to gradually increase spiritual engagement.
segments.transcript: If you are having idea of a continuing material existence, then, when this body, the term of life, in this body is over, if I have to continue material existence, I have to get another material body. That's called repetition of birth and death. So, to purify this mind means to stop this repetition of birth and death. That means to end all activities of the mind, all plans for continuing material existence, or rather, change material existence to spiritual existence. Now, Srila Prabhupada says, one has to situate oneself in pure spiritual life. Therefore, we should practice. Therefore, we should practice. Begin with spiritual life. Let's say, just chant 108 times Hare Krishna every day. It just takes about 10 minutes. So, out of 24 hours in a day, 10 minutes at least, perform spiritual activity, whereby 10 minutes you are not engaging the mind in material activity. The mind becomes engaged in spiritual activity. So, this is a very important point. And gradually go on increasing the spiritual activity, thereby reducing the engagement of the mind in material activities. And by the time you retire from all your material responsibilities, you should have completely changed all your engagements of the mind from material to spiritual. It means go on increasing your spiritual activities

segments.key_quote: When the mind is purified, and that means the mind is constantly engaged in the service of the Lotus Feet of the Lord, then at the time of death, the mind will not produce another material body, but the mind will actually enable the soul to go back home, back to God.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the concept of Sadhana Bhakti, the 64 principles of devotional service, and emphasizes the importance of associating with dedicated devotees to learn how to manage material duties while minimizing material engagement of the mind, ultimately leading to liberation.
segments.transcript: by which you engage the mind in spiritual life. Therefore, the program of Sadhana Bhakti is how to increase the activities that we perform through the body, words, and mind, more and more in devotional service. So, there are 64 principles of Sadhana Bhakti, different varieties of engagement in spiritual life. Why 64? Why so many? Because in different ways, we are engaging our body, words, and mind in material activities. So, if we have to spiritualize our engagement of the mind, we have to find different varieties of engagement for the mind through the body, through the words, and through the mind. So, therefore, there are 64 activities. And one by one by one, we should start adding those activities to our daily routine. Just like chanting Hare Krishna, then singing Hare Krishna, then offering food to Krishna, either a picture of Krishna or a deity of Krishna, accepting Prasadam after offering food, then reading the spiritual literature, Bhagavad Gita, Bhagavatam, hearing about Krishna's pastimes, like that. So many different engagements are possible and increase the engagements. Now, how do the engagements become more and more?
